column1: I feel fed up. Normally I'm not this angry but fuck it. After spending so many years trying to do well in school, be a good person, a good worker, a good wife, I feel it's all bullshit. Nobody cares about anyone but themselves. People offer you advice but really it's just self aggrandizing and makes them feel better about themselves. People want to be better, and some are so shitty that they'll abuse others at their own expense. We ignore the people who need the most help, the most hurt, ignored, gentle people. And glorify the shitheads who take our money in the name of some political or religious endeavor when really they're just sociopath types who don't give a fuck about anyone.  We put on airs and pretend we have this fucking life figured out when we're just evolved mammals on this billions of year old rock making up stupid shit and stories about God and what's real. None of it is real, love exists if we choose to believe it in our minds, no one is coming to save us. Even philosophy seems like a waste of time. What's the point?

Lately, I have been seeing a lot of comments here <e1>about how children cannot have bipolar disorder. That is not what recent research and practice supports.</e1> In fact, in the past 10 years there has been a huge leap forward in understanding that children DO get bipolar disorder and simply display symptoms differently than many adults do. Many kids rapid cycle and/or have mixed states. Few have euphoric mania, though some do.My son is 8, has bipolar disorder, and is in a study at NIH where they are examining MRI's related to early onset bipolar.So please, <e2>before you diagnose (or contradict a diagnosis) related to bipolar disorder in children....STOP</e2>. You could be making a big mistake, and hindering a parent's understanding and support of his or her child.Also, yeah- this could definitely mean you were not given good medication and therapy as a kid. And that sucks.
My boss and another co-worker will at least sit in during the interviews for an open position for our team, but since I'm technically the senior between the two of us by a month

To make a long story short,<e1>I had a deep craving for cigarettes and energy drinks and no money</e1>, so <e2>I attempted to shoplift from a supermarket and failed.</e2> <e3>My grandmother had to bail me out,</e3>and now <e4>I've lost any trust my family had in me.</e4>When I get cravings like this, my brain goes on autopilot. I don't think of the consequences, and the thrill of the occasion takes my mind away from reality. It's really, unforgivably stupid to behave like this, and I can't help but get caught up in the occasion.I embarrassed myself and my family, and I am building a horrible reputation for myself, digging a hole that goes deeper and deeper every time I dig.

I am a senior in college and <e1>I haven't made any friends my entire college career.</e1>It's due to <e2>a mix of SA, depression, (regular?) anxiety, ect.</e2> I have 1 year left and want to make at least 1 friend before I graduate. I am so embarrassed by this. I walked around campus looking for clubs to join, and I saw a few that interested me.<e3>One had a meeting today and I stood outside the door, froze, and left</e3> because <e4>I felt uncomfortable going by myself.</e4>I didn't know anyone in the clubs or organizations so I got scared. How do I overcome this? I hate talking to people. I even work in a Dr office where everyone chit chats and I sit there without saying anything.

Ok, so <e1>there's this girl I've liked for like ever. now, and my friend who's good friends with her told me that she likes me.</e1> <e2>I then realized that I'm too awkward and anxious to even talk to her.</e2>

This seems to be a popular way to go. I'm almost convinced I'm going to do it. Everywhere I read says to compress the carotid artery in order to lose consciousness but it seems difficult to do. I tried a couple of test runs (people say you should never test it because it might work but that doesn't really matter for me either way) and basically what happened is the ringing in my ears got louder and louder and my head felt like it was going to explode. It didn't feel like I was going to pass out though. Also <e1>I have a sore throat now</e1> from <e2>all the test-strangulations</e2>, luckily my voice is still fine though. I can't help but think it won't be much longer until I do this for real. I'm going to get super drunk and down a bunch of sleeping pills and anxiety meds before I do it.

Maybe reality isn't the right word.<e1>But a trigger of some sort, a bad day, lack of sleep, lack of exercise.</e1> Then <e2>it escalates to anxiety or depression, or an argument, or just general negativity and impulsiveness or laziness.</e2> Then <e3>everything looks bleaker afterward.</e3> Maybe rightfully so. I felt like I went months thinking it's going to be ok and I'm doing my best. But actually I'm not, and been making some impulsive decisions involving drinking again that make me take a step back. Im feeling lonely and isolated and that's not cool. Plus I'm only working part time and I realize it's time to step it up and be an adult again. I've honestly been a child for too long, in some ways, and do have issues that need to be addressed.Most of all, I'm feeling disconnected with my emotions and some sort of soft spot" that makes me feel closer to people

I never know. I shift to who you want me to be.That's manipulative, but why be someone who hates me?I want love too.I will do anything to get one person to love me.And when I open up?It all goes away...I don't belong with anyone.I am a mistake.

I'm having trouble focusing on meetings at the workplace. Most times, most of what is said doesn't apply to me so it doesn't hurt too much if I zone out. But once in a while it does and it's incredibly embarrassing. But in general, <e1>I contribute much less to meetings than I would like to</e1> due to <e2>zoning out</e2>. I've never followed along any of my classes and always learned the material on my own and I don't see myself following along in the meetings in the near future.I don't want to disclose that I have ADHD to my employer, especially considering I work in Singapore. This is a really difficult situation for me that I feel like is really hurting me professionally. Ideally, it would be nice if all assignments given to me were written down so I could read it at my own pace. Should I just request it?

So I've been noticing some things. When <e1>I get really angry</e1>, <e2>my bones start to shake</e2>. I get the rush of blood and thrill of being angry. But I have managed to NOT say anything I would regret soon after. I was just wondering, is it normal to feel excited when you're angry?

I have had anxiety and depression my whole life. I take medications and see my doctor regularly... probably 1 a week. I'm looking for other ways to combat my anxiety.When I was still with my long term partner I found physical contact to help a lot, unfortunately you cannot really expect friends and family to rub your back or hold you when you're experiencing anxiety all the time.I have tried aroma therapy but sometimes scents begin to be associated with memories and become triggers.I try asmr before bed to help me relax and have a therapy cat that I pet when my chest is so tight I can't breathe.I drink tea like chamomile....I don't know what else to do... <e1>I feel so anxious all the time now</e1> since <e2>the end of my relationship</e2> and I feel I'm always in pain not just from the heart break but chest pains and dread of dying.What would help me?I also have health issues and have a tumor that doctors are looking into and have body pains and nausea from stress that makes me throw up when I'm overwhelmed.What are good coping methods?

Sometimes I feel like a ticking time bomb just ready to explode. The slightest little nudge in the right direction sometimes will make me want to scream and use my fists to pummel a person into the ground. The only reason <e1>I haven't imploded in public</e1> is simply because <e2>my mom told me it wouldn't be worth it</e2>. I'm not usually that angry all the time but in some moments I just feel it creep up onto my shoulders. And when I don't take it out, the feeling just rests on my shoulders the whole day until I get some privacy. I can feel my self control diminishing rapidly but I still try to be sensible when things go rough. When I finally get some privacy, I just start screaming and punching the wall until my knuckles go red.I don't know, I just wanted to put my two cents.

In the last few months i became very convinced that cortisol levels play a major role in anxiety, panic attacks and depression, i came to this conclusion through personal blood test results, and the changing levels of anxiety through the day that are identical to the Cortisol daily cycle, starting at very high levels with 30 min of waking up and fluctuating during the day, so here is a link to the drugs that i found that could help with lowering Cortisol and had success in lowering anxiety depression levels, i only selected the drugs that have been researched and my main source of information was :US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health, hope it will be useful to some and would like to hear your thoughts about it, the difficult part is finding a Doctor who has a good understanding in psychiatry and Endocrinology and who would have an open mind to new ideas

I needed to get this out, just to put it down somewhere.I have been suffering dealing with anxiety for a little over 18 months now. As soon as I beat one thing (I could never sit in a car, or on a plane...I now do both without a care - I could never sit in a restaurant, now I eat out regularly) something else crops up and comes for me.Since July May I have been having negative thoughts...disturbing thoughts. I don't want to die, far from it, but my mind always triggers and says things like yeah you'l be gone soon" or just fixates on me dying

I had nearly three years clean and smoked weed for the past year, daily, all day, main priority. Fake rationalized manageability, and drifted away from aa completely. Did not drink. Stopped smoking a week ago, it was causing problems and my sig o helped me re-evaluate my new old new habit. I want to go back to the rooms but <e1>i am confused scared frustrated</e1> about <e2>picking up a white chip still having not drank</e2>. My sickness says if i am picking up a white chip why not have some drinks. I am worried I will resent myself...or something. Anyone relate?EDIT: Thank you folks for the reminder of how it really is. I have been basing a lot of real feelings on hypothetical conversations and situations while the reality is that my cannabis use was kicking up the same behaviors and was leading me back to the drink. It is the first big step in the wrong direction. Not many people have the opportunity to come close to the edge and check themselves. What I learned from yall and reaching back out to an old friend from the rooms is that I need to get back in there and do the thing. Thanks.

Currently having STRONG delusions of seeing hearing my husband in my mind with other people.  It's not his character to be like that and I am afraid of wearing him down. I work with people who I am  afraid of are poisoning my water and talking bad about me.Sometimes people show up at my work assignments and I think they were sent to kill me. My voices" are movies in my mind and I am watching the worst things happen

I wanted to post this on reddit before requesting Dr. Google for a consult. I'm on a generic medication, which my Pharmacist says, the only difference between what i'm taking and the Brand Adderall is that Adderall is a timed release pill. I'm taking Amphetamine Salts". I take about 40 mg every day. I've been on the medication for nearly 3 months but something unusual is happening. I'm still awake and alert after 27 hours! Can someone help explain? Is this because of My medication? "

...well, I have no clue exactly how many, but it's climbing every hour.Anyone else read a post, have this internal monologue where you ride your train of thought off to points unknown, get a few dozen words down in a reply, and out of nowhere realize wait a minute

so, <e1>he gave me some paperwork to fill out and send back to him</e1> so <e2>he has documentation for the diagnoses</e2>, but said ill be starting on concerta i think 32 something? then checking in 2 weeks after to make any adjustments we need.<e3>I'm glad</e3> to <e4>have a doctor that listens and doesnt think im some dumb junkie</e4>.

The first time, I put the clothes in and forgot to turn the washing machine on.The second time, I turned it on and let it do the whole cycle before realizing I had completely forgot to add detergent.The third time I finally did it and went to hang the clothes out to dry, only to get distracted by something else in the middle of it and leave half of them still in the basket.Nailed it! Explaining ADHD to my boyfriend was way easier after this.

This is what my life feels like at the moment, and I'm interested to hear if any of you have the same experience, and how do you deal with it?Recently diagnosed at 27, so many things started making sense.My main symptoms are attention related. Really poor memory (short term mainly), no sense of time, major focus issues when surrounded by noise/other stimuli.However, I've managed to hold down a decent job in construction management (lol) and I'm currently building my own house out of hours.I know how important diet, excercise and sleep are for this condition. I've seen how much my symptoms improve when these are managed even slightly better.The issue is, as I become more focused on being productive, I become exponentially worse at managing my health, relationships, and anything else really. I guess it's also worth mentioning I relate closer to an introverted temperament, but can be very social under the right circumstances.So, how do you guys keep yourself on track?

I never really thought about peeing before it was just something I did. Then I read a tweet on Twitter about someone who does that now when I go pee everytime I get tons of anxiety and I sometimes hold my breath now. How do I stop doing this?? I've tried focusing on breathing while peeing but my face gets red even though I'm breathing. How can I just forget about this and start peeing normally again? I've tried sitting too. This is really bothering me. What should i do? I feel embarrassed posting this but I don't know who I can tell..

I'm 18, living with my mom. I have been diagnosed with Aspergers and an anxiety disorder(I don't know what type).Recently, I have been struggling with intrusive thoughts (mostly sexual), and even though it goes in and out, I feel like I may need help. But I am afraid oftalking to my mother about it. What can I do

I have been struggling with getting stuff done. A good day is remembering to eat and completing one small task. I've been trying desperately to create  a way to get stuff done. Breaking tasks down into smaller bites, writing all my tasks in one spot, picking a list of 6 items to try to complete..... But I have no motivation to complete anything ( although I might start and half finish things that have peaked my interest, until I've lost my focus).I'm not medicated, been on the waiting list for any local psychiatrist for 3! Years.  The most I can get from a regular doc is Wellbutrin.  Have tried all other non stimulant options with no luck) I do lift weights most days, so I'm not missing the exercise aspect.TLDR : I wish there was something I could take do to get a quick motivation boost.Does anyone have any tips or tricks for motivation boosts for getting boring  but necessary stuff done?

So, I tell him about my miserable life and eventually cry. He tells me, Its going to be OK. When do you want to come again?" Where's the medication or career help? Is this normal?How long into the therapy are you formally diagnosed and treated?"

DR: is there a drug or something similar that I can take which inhibits the survival instinct?For the past years I have disappointed all my relatives. I kept telling them I would take all my exams year after year. But each time I spend less and less time studying. I lost all my drive to do anything. Originally I would study 1 week before the exams, then turned that to the day before the exam, the night before the exam and now I reached the point where I would lie to myself that I would study the next day" but in the end not even open the book. While I know this isn't too relevant to my question

Hi guys, <e1>just posting here</e1> so <e2>I have something solid to say</e2> that I started and looking for any kind of tips or suggestions people might have for staving off boredom. I've got plans to study loads for the pre-christmas college exams, start getting violin lessons, read a lot more, I've changed my diet so I'm losing weight, spend more time with my girlfriend and friends. I've decided that when I complete the 90 day detox i'm going to have a serious look at how I've done over the 90 days and whether or not I want to go back.<e3>I'm open to any suggestions for how to spend time that doesn't involve having money</e3> cause <e4>I'm a student</e4>.

I am getting my tonsils out on Monday. <e1>I'm really nervous and anxious about it</e1> since <e2>it's my first major surgery</e2>. Any advice or anything could help. I'm trying not to think about it and work myself up more. But every day it gets closer, I'm more freaked out.

So my wife had her first ever episode of anxiety about a week ago, she was at my daughters gymnastics practice and she felt dizzy and afraid she might pass out and left.  After working through her symptoms etc we determined she was having anxiety.  She has been fighting through it this last week and making a lot of progress but tonight  Las we walked into gymnastics she was instantly overcome with the sake feeling.  Full body numbness fear of passing out.  What can she do to work through this, should she just avoid gymnastics or try to overcome it?

<e1>She</e1> was all I had and probably the reason <e2>I'm still alive</e2>. I loved her more than anything else in my life. Everything we planned out together is no more. I have no more future to look forward to. I had originally planned to kill myself by a certain time (next summerish) until I met her. Now I don't know what to do. Please make the pain go away...

I feel like <e1>the older I get the worse my anxiety gets and I'm just so tired</e1>. <e2>I'm tired of constantly needing reassurance from myself and other people that it will be okay</e2>. <e3>I'm tired of feeling like crying Every moment leading up to anything</e3>. <e4>I'm tired of feeling pains of hunger but also feeling constantly on the verge of throwing up</e4>. <e5>I'm tired of the fact that no matter how many times I calm myself down and I start feeling better, the slightest change sends me spiraling</e5>. <e6>I'm tired of constantly saying to myself I can't quit my job</e6>. <e7>I'm tired of wanting to reach out to friends but holding back because I'm just overreacting</e7>. <e8>I'm tired of when I do post on my blog no one cares but hey post a gif of youtubers and hey look at all the notes.I'm tired of constantly reminding myself that no ending it all isn't the cure</e8>.  <e9>I'm tired of being this anxiety filled girl who wants to just stay in her room all day</e9>. I just don't know what to do anymore.

<e1>I've had enough of feeling massively depressed and worthless</e1> so <e2>I bought a 9mm pistol</e2>. I have wasted my life away and can't live with myself. Since <e3>I can't become somebody else there's nothing else to do</e3> but <e4>kill myself</e4>. My note is written. Now I'm going to drive to the place where the biggest disappointment of my life took place and blow my brains out there at the exact time of day when it happened. I tried therapy and every other conceivable way of dealing with life. So this isn't a rash decision. People will quickly forget about me. Goodbye

I have one of those jobs where nothing can be traced back to me, and one where talking to someone would just as easily end it. I was abused as a child, I drink to suppress the pain of being abused as a child. I smile and hold friendly conversations with my peers, but really at the end of the day, I think day in and day put about ending my life. Tonight I held a loaded gun to my head to see how it felt, with the cold steel against my head. I'm honestly not even sure why I'm here, I want to seek help but I can't without it impacting what I do. I don't want to end what little fragile life I have, but I don't know how much longer I can deal with the pain and suffering. (Before anyone tries, this came through TOR, on public wifi from live CD boot image)

<e1>Texting gives me so much anxiety it makes me physically sick to my stomach</e1>.  <e2>I feel like I can never express myself the exact way I want to over text</e2>.  </e3><e3>I almost always end up feeling like I've accidentally offended the other person based on what I perceive their tone to be</e3>.  Or that <e4>I've annoyed them beyond reason and ruined any relationship they might have wanted or had with me</e4>.On top of that, <e5>I never quite understand texting etiquette</e5>.  When is the conversation over?  At what point are my responses just annoying the other person?  If I keep asking questions or keep responding in a leading way is that rude?  And yet sometimes <e6>I feel like if I let a conversation end then I'm risking that person thinking I'm rude or- more likely- forgetting about me completely</e6>.And, of course, <e7>there's the standard when-will-they-respond anxiety on top of all of that</e7>.<e8>I have similar anxieties with emails</e8>, though I feel like I have a better grasp of how email etiquette works.  Does texting, or written communications in general, give anyone else this much anxiety?  What do you guys do when such a necessary task becomes unbearably terrifying?

Hi guys. I'm a healthy, 18 year old male. Got a girlfriend that I am super attracted to about 2 weeks ago. About a month ago my dick stopped acting like a normal hormone fueled dick. Getting hard almost never happens. Ever. Jerking off feels so forced. I literally comfortably went a week without doing anything and can't remember if I got hard at all during that week. Anyways onward to the Girl. We'll call her Danny. Super sweet, smart, perfect and extremely attractive. I hit a homerun with this one. We are super happy together. But I just struggle to maintain an erection for long enough to transition into anything past 2nd base. I guess my question is, is this normal? Is it a thing some developing teens occasionally go through? Please help. A month ago I could jerk off to a trash bag if it looked feminine enough. Now <e1>I have this beautiful fucking woman in my life and I can't do anything</e1>. I want to. <e2>I'm nervous</e2>. I dont want her to think Im not attracted to her. Help. Please help this is killing me.

<e1>I need help</e1>. <e2>I am the man who has all the opportunity as do all of us, but I don't know what I want or how to find it</e2>. I'm never happy anymore and I don't know if I can find happiness again. I'm just tired of having everything go wrong always. Yes, Which shit covered sandwich would you like today?"

I don't know what the fuck happened. I was doing so well. Then I just suddenly stopped eating. I have no energy, no joy. <e1>I just ruined my friends board game night</e1> because <e2>I was so quiet and mopey the whole time</e2>. I know they were glad when I left. I should have left sooner. My life is going nowhere. I'm a broken waste of resources. I know nobody will read this. I just want to get this off my chest. I also want to cry but I can't because I'm not right.

<e1>I got drunk last night</e1>, and <e2>got highly emotional</e2>. I woke up this morning after sweating out of my bed from nightmares, and my mindstate is still the same as last night when I was drunk. <e3>It scares me</e3>. <e4>I want to visit my girl and just cry, but I will not see her for 2 weeks</e4>. It all was going so smoothly, my first 3.5 weeks, with no intention of caving or craving, but now I am at an all time low and I just want to smoke to stop my head from going crazy and numb myself instead of crying and feeling sorry for myself.What the fuck do I do when I just want to lay down and cry? I don't want to cave, and I am not going to. But I feel like shit, and that's an understatement. Someone please relate or drop a kind word, I could use it for sure, I need to stop my thoughts today from being a one-way direction towards smoking.

<e1>I was listening to to ADHD Rewired podcast the other day about calendars and also about todo-list</e1>. <e2>It got me started thinking about what I miss from having a paper-calendar the main thing being to scribble down cancelled subscription </e2>.

Any Australians here that's prescribed schedule 8 medication know of the regulations around getting your repeats filled? I'm about a week out from it being a month since I last had a script filled for vyvanse and can't find my remaining pills, misplaced them somewhere at home. Can I get my next repeat now? Or are there strict regulations in place? No big deal if I have to wait a week. I may find them between now and then anyway, but also curious about the answer to this I can't find much info online

A guy I really liked let go of me. Why is this happening? I know I'm far from the only one doing this. Are we doing this to make ourselves feel worse and justify the need of taking our lives even more? Are we afraid of how nothing will work out the second we lay our eyes upon them?I can't stand this cycle. It's like I'm unconsciously trying to maim myself even more and show everyone what a wreck I am while also trying to hide it. I think I'm able to repress my thoughts but when I actually meet up with someone and feel close to them, I show them the 'real' me which is in stark contrast to the 'me' they talked to before.I am so sorry for anyone ever crossing paths with me.

<e1>i am at one of my lowest points in my life</e1>, <e2>i feel so alone</e2>, <e3>i tried to take my life last night</e3>and i don't know what to do, the person i would normaly talk to before i got this low is on holiday and the counseler at my collage is useless. i just need some one i can talk to and not have them tell me what to do just listen. im sorry this is a bit rambly i just don't know what to do.
<e1>So frustrated right now</e1>. <e2>They signed me up for this stupid moon festival celebration just to show me off to their friends</e2>. They already paid for the tickets. ><

<e1>I've always brushed it off as not being a social person</e1> but <e2>whenever I'm in a conversation with someone else my mind won't let me say the things I'm thinking</e2>. Then I just end up thinking instead of talking. I don't know what I'm afraid of. I don't know if I'm afraid or insecure or whatever. If someone else could explain what social anxiety feels like to them, what goes on in your head when you interact with someone, I would really appreciate it because I don't know how to explain it.

Hi All,I've been NC with my family for 3 months.  I have a one year old - the first grandchild.   <e1>I just took a pregnancy test that was faintly positive</e1>.  <e2>My husband and I are excited</e2> and we will take another test in a couple days.  I know I will struggle with whether or not to tell them and, if so, when. What do you all think?Thank you!

My Nmom loves social media. I've blocked her on everything except Facebook because fb is now for your whole family and advertisers anyway. I used to only pay attention to the thinly veiled insults towards me, but I realized Facebook lays bare her language and gaslighting nature for everyone to see. Case in point, she posted a couple of pictures of her and a friend doing tourist stuff together. Captioned it This was a fun day with (friend)". One of her friends commented "Isn't everyday a fun day with (friend)?" My mom responds "Absolutely! That's why I said another..."Boom! Gaslighting in public. Can't even bother to edit her original post to include the word "another". This made me giddy for some reason. Tell me stories about your narc and social media. Anyone else notice anything like this?"

i've felt like this since i was a little kid. like every moment i'm still alive is taking time away from someone else. like i don't deserve to be here and all i do is waste valuable resources without contributing anything at all. like i'm a black hole that just keeps sucking up stuff and sucking up stuff and sapping all the good out of the worldi feel like everything i have would be better as someone else's, but i'm too selfish to give anything away.i just want everything to stop. i don't know if i really want to be dead or not. mostly, i just want to go to sleep forever. i want to be able to sleep forever, but also be able to wake up any time and go on with life. maybe i just want the option of making it permanent while being able to back out any time. like i could wake up if i wanted, but i could also just sleep forever too.i don't know if this is suicidal thinking or just being really tired of being alive.

<e1>Whenever I hear sadness called something to do with diet or amount of sleep it really ticks me off</e1> because <e2>it is so belittling to somebody trying deal with depression</e2>. It makes our problems sound so small as if we just caught a cold and someone tells us we should dress warmer. Like they believe it's a tiny irk with an easy fix. It's not. It's crippling and life threatening. It just shows that there's a grand confusion about what depression is by people who don't suffer from it. They don't understand what we go through but they act as if they know all the solutions we need. I just feel so much animosity for the total lack of help available to us. But you probably know about this already cause you're awesome. Thanks for reading.

If you hide your depression/anxiety and don't want people to know but you kind of get angry that they don't even notice.  <e1>It makes me feel angry</e1> because <e2>it means I'm not that close to anyone for them to even notice</e2>. I know it sounds strange and I'd never tell anyone but the way I am I'm suprised no one has said are you okay? You seem different. Even though I'd say I'm fine it's kind of a horrible feeling that no one has noticed.

Hi.So, I'm like a closet-depressed person. I have certain triggers that will hit me, and once they do, I get so far down you'd need a super drill to find me again. Today is one of those days - *and it's not an appropriate one*. I've recently hit a happy period of my life, and met someone that now matters a lot to me. I'm not yet ready to introduce this person to the dark hole that is my depression. I realize it's going to have to happen some day, but I'm not ready to have that day come this week. So I need to keep a positive outlook and not appear as broken as I feel.What do you guys do to get momentarily over your depression in order to function in your day to day life? I cannot figure this out right now on my own, and I **need** this sorted out asap.

I'm a freshmen, moved in a few weeks ago. I don't have any friends here. The dorm I live in is very large, and has suites of 8 people, all sharing a bathroom. My roommate and the rest of my suitemates are  unfriendly. <e1>I want drugs more than anything</e1>. <e2>I want to get high and be happy and have a good time</e2>. But doing it on my own is just going to make me even more sad.I can't handle another day of this. What reason do I have to even try to keep going?

Sorry if I am misusing any acronyms, I am new to this subreddit and reddit in general.I have been learning more about npd since my therapist told me that my dad was narcissistic. The main thing that my Ndad does is gaslight me (and my entire family). He is a liar and I worry that I am starting to lie as well. I am not doing it on purpose, but I catch myself lying or pretending not to know/not having done something when I am called out. I've been binge-watching The Good Wife, and one of the minor characters on the show, Elsebeth Tascioni, is a brilliant lawyer who is pretty eccentric in a way that <e1>seems to strongly suggest that she has ADHD</e1>. Even though it is never explicitly stated that she has ADHD, <e2>her character is frequently distracted</e2> and <e3>seems to constantly have 10 different trains of thought</e3>. What I really like about her character is that she is represented as someone who is quirky, but is brilliant and well-respected at her job. She is also able to focus very well on her cases (which I interpret as hyperfocus), which is something that I really relate to in terms of hyperfocusing on my areas of interest. Do any of you agree with this interpretation? Are there any other similar characters you can think of from TV/movies who are like this? I think it is really refreshing to have someone with these traits represented in a way that is more nuanced, and I would like to know if there are other noteworthy examples.

So I still notice myself sometimes trying to line up my feet in a certain way along with the sidewalk cracks and if my teeth touch in my mouth I sit and touch my teeth together on the other side to even it out" but I don't think these things I do are something people notice me doing.  I probably only waste 30 mins to an hour a day doing random things like this. I have a weird obsession with symmetry with it. Like if I accidentally rub my hand on the right side of a walk bridge I just have to do it with my left hand to even it out. I can fight the urge and forget it ever happened quickly. <e1>When I get angry I grind my teeth a lot</e1> so <e2>it's been noticeable lately</e2> because <e3>my new job is horridI</e3> also am sorry if I shouldn't have this in the ADHD forum at all but I know that the OCD is common in ADHD folks."

I was diagnosed with ADD when I was about 13, but had relatively low working memory scores in an IQ test I had to take to get into a school program. <e1>I had incredible difficulties in paying attention, but never had the 'hyperactive' disorders growing up</e1>, so <e2>I was diagnosed with ADD and medicated accordingly</e2>. Around 16 or so something changed. I was able to sit down and just read or study something for long stretches of time if I wanted to (especially if I wasn't stressed out), and gradually I just kept getting better and better even without my meds. Concentration is more a product of volition rather than chance: If I want to be able to focus I can, and sometimes if I'm really interested I can focus with incredible detail. ;nbsp;For those diagnosed with ADD, have you felt like you've become more focused the older you've gotten? And as such has your working memory improved at all?TL;DR: did anyone who was diagnosed with ADD as a child 'grow out' of it?

I am realizing that one reason <e1>I still feel bad about separating myself from my dad</e1> is because of <e2>how frequently he puts on this pitiful</e2>, dejected face. I just have so many visions of him in my head like this over the years.In the past (from a pretty young age) I always tried to comfort him, and encourage him, and tell him things would be okay. This post has been very helpful in the leaves subreddit for people dedicated to not smoking weed anymore. People think they're fixing the system by getting rid" of the bad kids

<e1>After a two year habit</e1>, <e2>three rehab visits</e2>, and <e3>4 overdoses (at 20-21)</e3> <e4>I've finally made it through the worst of it</e4>. My boyfriend is on day 4 too, and I'm proud we made it this far. The last two attempts, we made it 48 hours. I'm carless atm, but I know that I'll have a ride by Thursday and I'm hoping I can be strong enough not to use. It's been a fucking trip. I just hit the insomnia state and am literally downing pedilyte, vitamins, Imodium, Tylenol, 5htp, Xanax, and hella weed. The worse is about to be over and I can't fucking wait.

Maybe this will resonate with some of you. I was never a text book alcoholic, hell most of us aren't  weren't - but I was a binge drinker. Important to mention that alcohol wasn't always a problem, even when I was drinking heavily. In my 20's I seemed to have this power to bounce back from any drinking sessions and would write off the bad experiences to being young and doing dumb shit. But then I started getting older. About 5 years ago I finally admitted I had an issue. One thing in particular worth mentioning is that the respect you get from others when you drink heavily diminishes. People start treating you in a certain way, they start taking you for granted and you get side tracked - etc. Even by people who've only known you during the times you were sober. At first I used to explain this away with People are just selfish assholes". Inside I felt the same

Another routine trip through woods and fields - the guard at the gate made his usual joke about us being there every week, logged us in on his clipboard and told the guard upstairs in the tower to open the first gate.Inside through another series of gates, we greeted people chatting some and then the meeting started - reading the ninth step (making amends - always an interesting if not loaded topic in prison where the state is extracting some form thereof)...and with people for whom amends is not always feasible.The format is that we each read a paragraph or two but that it can be interrupted if someone is struck by what is written.  One man spoke about the women on his list. And the fact that his wife had said she wanted to be a part of the process.  and yeah, here we come to a big problem with the ninth step - just about every man (can not speak for women) gets a strong urge to find old phone books - and say some version of , hey I'm sober

So I've always convinced myself that I didn't have a problem, despite what family and close friends have told me for years. It's incredible how long it takes to finally realize what others have been saying for a very long time. <e1>This last weekend I was a total drunk jackass for four days straight. You guys know the feeling; get too drunk and act a fool, wake up the next morning and hop back on the exact same wagon for no apparent reason</e1>. So <e2>Sunday night I finally accepted that I have a problem and changes are necessary</e2>. I've destroyed 3 of life's very important Bs for too long: body, brain, and bank account. This is my 4th day and I'm super optimistic about this change. I've been drinking nothing but tea and water, and while the cravings haven't come yet, they're bound to happen but I know I will stay strong. This community is so helpful and accepting. Thanks for being yourselves, everyone. I will not drink with any of you today.
So I guess this is it, 24 hours down and the rest of my life in front of me. I feel free right now. I can do whatever I want to without waiting to sober up to drive. Here goes.

I just keep holding his hand and praying the rosary over him. I am so sad. I'm going to keep praying this is all I can do! Staying sober through death the first time in my life. I will keep you all posted how it goes.

Hey guys, just wanted to see if anyone had similar experiences - I was diagnosed about 4 months ago and while initially Vyvanse was a godsend I quickly grew tolerant and while some of the focusing effects remained, I lost any volition to do work, became angry, apathetic and withdrawn. I also noticed the peripheral effects (High HR ; BP) were all that was left along with an irritable mood after awhile. I did take breaks at least on the weekends and even had an extended break for a few weeks when I went on vacation. <e1>My doctor offered to bump me up to 70mg but at one point I even tried taking 2x50's out of frustration of the lack of beneficial effects and that didn't help at all</e1> so ,<e2>I denied it</e2>. We're doing a trial run of Adderall XR 30mg (I also have the option of doing Vyvanse + a booster of IR Adderall in the future) and I noticed that I'm much less irritable and way less anxious as well. I got a mild euphoric" feeling for a day or two but that goes away as we all know

And even though I'm dead tired today, I could be in a lot worse shape if I had taken a drink. I could be sitting here at my desk, sick to my stomach, dizzy from my sharp, pounding headache, hungry but not hungry, and overall miserable. But I'm not! The worst thing is that I'm a little sleepy, but I'm about to make myself a cup of coffee which should help with that.The best thing of all, I was able to drive home last night without any worries. I am loving feeling good about my decisions and about myself. Feels good man.Also, I met up with some of my old concert buddies last night and I don't know what they were on (ketamine? Ecstacy? Is there something else I haven't heard of?) and it was really difficult to hold a conversation with them, or even be around them. They kept bumping into people, pushing, shoving, and talking nonsense. Is that what I used to be like? Ugh. Gross.I also had a revelation that even though I'm really awkward at sober small talk, it turns out other people are awkward too. I'm not alone.

I realized I probably take more from this sub than I contribute.I'd like to offer up something that's been SUPER helpful for me, in the hopes that it'll help you guys too.Today, take out a piece of paper and a pen. Don't cheat and do this on your phone or on your computer, actually write it down on paper!Write down a list of your fears, today. I'm not talking abstract. <e1>Real fears</e1>.A) <e2>Sally might never text me back</e2>.B) <e3>Account R isn't going to renew their contract</e3>.C) <e4>I'm going to lose my house</e4>.D) <e5>I'm going to lose my job</e5>.E) <e6>I'm going to lose my wife</e6>.F) <e7>My family will judge me for not drinking</e7>.G) <e8>I'm a fraud and will be discovered by the end of the year</e8>.H) <e9>One of these nutjobs is going to be President</e9>.Take that piece of paper, fold it up, put it in a drawer, and look at it again in 30 days. This exercise was PROFOUNDLY important for me.99% of this shit I worried about never came true. It was all in my head. And now when I get scared, or anxious, I remind myself to turn that shit off.
Nothing seems more satisfying to me anymore than the thought of closing my eyes and never having to open them again

Today is different. I suppose it started last night - Instead of the typical feeling of anxiety that comes before bed, it was loneliness. I just felt so alone and pathetic. Waking up today was only worse. Bad stomach problems and such self loathing that Ive spent the day in tears thus far. Through all the confused fragmented imagery of my own despair, these memories that I spent years pushing down are all coming back up. The things that made me happy, the things that made me sad, the bad shit ive done to people - the bad shit ive done to myself. Its like listening to a radio static between stations, and every once in awhile I get a clear signal. It flickers, reminds me of something that I have been running from for so long, and then goes back to static. Just long enough to plant an image in my head... something beautiful and horrific. I dont hate the memories though. I hate that I dont know how to cope with them.I am so thankful to have Leaves to reflect on. You guys are keeping me square.

It's been 20 hours since my last drink, I've been tapering down from 10/12 units a night since February to 5/6 recently and thought I'd try a few days without. <e1>It's been going well today but in the last hour I've gotten a bit of a head tingly feeling</e1> that's <e2>gotten me a bit anxious</e2>, is that normal and ok or a sign I should be cutting down slower?

<e1>I need help staying sober</e1>, because <e2>right now I'm planning my relapse</e2>.I relied on alcohol to modulate several major areas of my behaviour: primarily as a vent against stress unhappiness/general shit, but it also served a key role in my appetite and sleep habits.Yes I know about the downsides - I wouldn't be here if I wasn't acutely aware how much it sucks to be drinking - but my problem is that none of the benefits of being sober line up with the benefits of being an alcoholic.Most of all, and I'm asking for specific help here: I need some way of venting stress, of being able to take a time-out from life. A shitty few days and a poor night's sleep are all it will take to derail me, to make me need to 'tap out'... and I don't want that relief to come from alcohol anymore, but I do fucking need that relief.And I'm sorry if this is out of bounds: but I'm perfectly happy to substitute other drugs for alcohol, other addictions even. Being an addict isn't my problem, being addicted to a substance where the 'high' is literally your body succumbing to poison is.

Hello there! Well, <e1>yesterday I completed 30 days of sobriety</e1>. <e2>Feeling really good</e2>. I seriously doubt not want to drink ever again. I'm just done. I hated that life. In only 30 days I have gained so much! I'm happy. I have more money. I don't miss work. My kids are a joy not a nuisance. I've lost 8 pounds. My Husband is happier. My mornings are energetic and positive. One thing that I started doing was keeping a journal. I think it helps to write. I plan on jotting down all of my rock bottoms. All of the horrible times. All of the shameful shit I did. So that when I think I've got this disease on lock and can go back out, I can read through all of my past mistakes. <e3>I need that reminder</e3> because <e4>I am really good at pretending shit didn't happen or wasn't that big a deal</e4>. Not going to happen this time. I'm arming myself with a lot of tools to fight this bitch disease and the disgusting relapses that too often plague me! I didn't drink today and in not drinking tomorrow!!!

I had 60 days sober and then two relapses that both lasted about 3 days each. I'm now on day 6 and feeling great again. This has been a big and wonderful life changing struggle. I really don't feel too bad about the relapses. I felt horrible afterwards but am glad that I pulled myself out of them.My husband of 2 years told me tonight that he doesn't want to be together anymore. It's heartbreaking news but at least I have a sober mind to deal with this.I don't know why I'm sharing. Just trying to stay positive. I have zero desire to drink right now and that feels pretty good.

<e1>Being raised as a kid by a religious mother, I've always been told, or been lead to understand, that being sexual was ok only after marriage and it shouldn't happen with multiple people</e1>...<e2>I'm 22 years old, and I still feel ashamed about being sexual</e2>. <e3>I feel that I do something wrong when I masturbate</e3>, or <e4>I am scared to go into relationships</e4> because <e5>I've never been able to keep a long term relationship</e5> and I feel like if I slept with more than one person, the next person that would come along would judge me for <e6>how many people I've slept with</e6> and <e7>wouldn't love me anymore</e7>..Ofc I don't judge other people for doing this, I just judge myself. I posted on this sub late august about a choice I had to make between leasing a party house or living with 2 roommates in a quiet house for this university semester. Everyone told me not to take the party house, but I took it anyways. I felt I had a chance and I really needed to make the most out of it. So far I am glad I did. It turns out the people here are all really cool. Theyre quiet most days and are pretty chill. They also invite me to play League and Fifa with them quite often which is also awesome. I am still a bit awkward sometimes but its progress and thats what matters. Also I was genuinely surpirsed and felt kind of guilty how I let my anxiety get to me and assumed because <e1>they were outgoing</e1>, that <e2>they would be assholes</e2>. Quite the opposite was true actually. Besides that I can study and have all my alone" time as well without being excessively bothered. So far things have been good. Im not saying they will always be this way

I think especially in a man's world harsh commentaries, competition and prestige is natural, but if you're socially anxious you have many blocks which prevent you from these things, and suddenly, when someone criticises something about your lacking social skills it hits super hard, and it makes people seem evil. Most of them don't know when they're being jerks that they are hitting in a place where it really hurts.In the past I assumed people were actually evil, but lately i've been thinking about it and I've decided that while there's a lot of cruelty even in daily life, people are no less or more evil than me, and if I empathise with a person who has no anxiety issues I understand where they come from and why to their view it's okay to say something shitty like You look like you don't know what you're doing" to me.No stockholm syndrome here. It doesn't mean I think it's okay

So I've been lurking in this subreddit for a bit; trying to find something that works for me to help me get over drinking (<e1>Can't anymore</e1> due to <e2>medications i'm on</e2>....but that hasn't been stopping the need).It kinda began with the concept of a happy place; that kinda place you build in your mind to help with depression and anxiety.Then it occured to me how much stuff I hate about drinking. <e3>The Taste, the burn, the After a night of binging</e3>....So <e4>I made a Bad place</e4>. a Place when I feel the addiction coming on I remember all the bad, horrible things I hate about drinking, how it feels, smells, looks, ....tastes....This has been cutting that addiction feeling right cold. sometimes badly enough I feel queasy for a few minutes. I'm not sure if it's a healthy way to do it, but it's working for me and I just wanted to maybe give some other people the idea to help cope with addiction.~Crystal

I've never tried Strattera (Only Vyvanse ; Adderall XR) but I've heard both good and bad things about it. People commonly mention that they deal with excessive sleepiness or loss of libido but I'm a little bit confused about how the sleepiness is induced. Strattera aka atomoxetine is an NRI but it's unique mechanism of action has it primarily acting in the brain rather than the periphery. As we know, norepinephrine is a stimulating catecholamine which is derived from dopamine and can be converted one step further to epinephrine. So wouldn't the theory be that increased norepinephrine levels promote vigilance, wakefulness, alertness, memory formation etc? I know I'm waay oversimplifying this med, but bear with me.

I frequently feel guilt about being so boring and predictable. I would much rather be encouraged to try new items. The worst is when I'm greeted with my typical order as soon as I arrive. <e1>It's like they already know they're getting my money regardless</e1>, so <e2>they might as well get rid of me as soon as possible</e2> so <e3>other people can give them money</e3>. <e4>I've worked retail</e4>, so <e5>I know I shouldn't take this personally</e5>, but it still hurts.Once this happens, I usually won't go back for at least a couple weeks, secretly hoping they'll forget about me.

Somewhere between moving states and establishing myself again in my home state, my whole emotional tree has been torn apart. <e1>Brace yourself</e1>, because <e2>this may end up very long</e2>.I got engaged to my high school sweetheart, moved across the country with him, and left everyone I knew behind. Somewhere in those four years, something changed, and when he slowly began to hate my company, and avoid me to play games online, or sleep all day, I told him I felt suicidal - like I was just a breath away from killing myself from depression. He had no words for me. No support, no objection, no emotion to what I was saying. I distinctly remember him driving us home from work, and me bursting into tears trying to tell him how much I was spiraling, and the blank look on his face as he just turned to me and said Okay".Fast forward to when we finally ended things and I told him I had to leave because I KNEW I was getting closer to really hurting myself

I smoke an average of 12 cigarettes a day, sometimes close to a pack a day if I'm bored or drinking. I've recently noticed that the rate at which I smoke has dramatically increased from what it was before I graduated college. So this draws me to the idea that <e1>a lot of the time I only smoke</e1> because <e2>I have nothing to occupy my time otherwise</e2>. I smoked about 13 cigarettes yesterday, I have had one so far today and want to keep it that way, and I feel that I can if I just stay adequately occupied. Perhaps I can cut down to 1 or 2 a day without severe repercussions, I smoked that one cigarette 5 hours ago and have yet to experience a strong craving. I've had a few cravings since then but they were not enough to get me to pull another one out of the pack, and I think that is a good sign. Just felt like sharing because I feel it helps me keep quitting" on my mind."

We've had a slow but steady number of people posting links asking persons suffering from anger management issues to please fill out their surveys or sign up for their services. These posts will be removed moving forward. They're not constructive, and the people who come to this sub don't participate in them. If you have come here with a survey, you're welcome to engage with users in the comments of their posts, but the first and foremost goal of any user needs to be to help the OP come to terms with their anger issues, or to foster discussion about coping techniques. Users posting only to promote a survey or service will be banned from this subreddit.

So I am currently in a master's program and I worked super hard to get into it. Unfortunately, my anxiety and panic attacks have been incredibly hard to deal with. I have been trying every coping mechanism but nothing really seems to be working. I started an IOP program at a treatment center near me and even that wasn't helping. I started meds and that calmed my anxiety a bit and I waited it out, but it still didn't do much. The panic attacks became worse and worse. I started having them twice a day. <e1>I asked my treatment center if I can go in for a higher level of care<e1> because <e2>I started having some suicidal thoughts</e2> and <e3>I'm just tired of living this way</e3>. My biggest fear was being dropped out of my master's program. They told me that they would work with me and fully support me, but I will graduate a year later and with a different cohort. This really upset me and is making me rethink my decision of going into the treatment facility. Any thoughts, tips, experience or advice? Anything would be appreciated.

I was wondering does anyone else experience complacency - be it school related, professional work, etc. - and stop putting in effort?<e1>I got diagnosed with ADHD-PI</e1> 3 months ago, and while medication has certainly helped me with motivation and a plethora of my other symptoms, it seems settling for complacency has been a lifelong habit of mine that managed to stick around... as it, including <e2>making a few careless but critical mistakes</e2>, <e3>got me fired from my job today</e3>.My whole life it has been most noticeable with school related stuff; at the beginning of my first school years, I had a way of putting in my absolute best effort and making astonishing progress, but then somewhere down the line be it 3 or 6 months it's as if my brain goes that's it

So I was one of the first to be diagnosed in the fourth grade as ADHD-PI (long enough ago that they called it ADHD-Non Hyperactive). <e1>Thanks to good parents and teachers</e1> <e2>I was able to develop some decent coping skills before starting on 10mg Ritalin in my Senior year of high school, which has carried me pretty effectively until today</e2> (some 7 years later).While I've overcome some obstacles, such as coming to grips with my ensuing depression and memory issues, most of the obstacles I've hit haven't been too daunting. The only exception being one bad habit:While I actively seek out the means to remain organized, I often find myself becoming bored with whatever system I'm currently using and discarding it quickly. After my schedule goes to complete disarray, I'll find some new fresh way to regain order and the cycle will repeat itself in another month or so.So my question is this: Those of you who've found effective means of calendering to-do lists, what was it that made them stick" or stay interesting and effective? What advice would you have for maintaining a calendar planner consistently?Edit: New to Reddit

I've had a few badge resets in the past few weeks, but I've successfully cut down a LOT. Still working toward zero and pretty happy with my progress. I noticed yesterday that it felt like it's been a week or two since I last drank, but then I looked at my badge and saw that it had only been 3 days. I was really surprised and it just reminded me to stay vigilant. I cancelled a meeting with some friends in a bar restaurant (I had planned to just have tea or ceffee) to make sure I wasn't tempted, and that felt pretty good.<e1>Yesterday I was really anxious all day, which was pretty unusual for me</e1> as <e2>I'm really not an anxious person</e2>, and <e3>I'm wondering if it could be an effect of detox</e3> as <e4>I really haven't gone three days without drinking in quite a long time, even if it feels like I have</e4>.Thanks for your support, guys. I just wanted to check in to keep myself on track this weekend. Maybe this time I'll make it to two weeks!

I get questioned by friends often about my ADD. I was diagnosed when I was 16, but I remember I sought the drug out, I can't remember why. I definitely am not hyper without it, I'm just non functioning (I'm 28 now). I'm studying for exams Right now and drove to my library and couldn't read. Just fucking couldn't. I realized I forgot my vyvanse, for the first time in forever. <e1>I had a breakdown and got so sad</e1> to <e2>realize how dependent I am</e2>. My question is, it's not always about being hyper, right? When I don't take it I can't even get out of bed. I can't stop the thoughts in my head, I can't focus. This is an indication for ADD meds, right? Have I been abusing it? <e3>My friends make me feel guilty</e3> because <e4>instead of calming me down to focus, it wakes me up for focus</e4>. I'm not all psycho like cleaning 8 hours, just functional and able to do day to day things.

and <e1>I feel like such a failure</e1>. <e2>I had 50 days of sobriety and threw it all away for one night of debauchery. I drank 9 beers and smoked about 10 cigarettes at home alon</e2>. And all it gave me was a throbbing headache, a horrible taste in my mouth, a sick stomach and a depressed feeling all day.However, all I can think about is how I will reset my badge and begin again. <e3>I hate being back at Day 1, but I'm going to use this feeling to  motivate me</e3> as <e4>I continue on my journey towards lasting sobriety</e4>.

He died last week at age 25. He was a funny guy with a huge heart and passionate about music. I was friends with him from elementary school into high school. <e1>Towards the end of high school we stopped hanging out</e1> because <e2>he got into hard drugs, and I preferred booze</e2>. I feel terrible for his parents who are incredible people.His death reminded me how close I came to going down that same path by messing around with vicodin, percocet, and booze. I made sure to tell my doctors my experiences with addiction so they don't prescribe me opiates ever again. Drinking lead me down some dark paths, and I am thankful that this sub helped me get in the right direction.

I am a married, childless woman. This morning I went through my calendar and had a realization: Last spring, I discovered I was pregnant. I discovered that hormones flipped a switch in my brain and turned me off to alcohol and other vices. It was amazing; I had no desire to be anything but 100% for this kid. Being alcohol-free was surprisingly easy. From the day I found out to the day I miscarried I was totally clean. <e1>It was super early in the pregnancy</e1> so <e2>it was disappointing</e2> but manageable. But I'm over 35 and have never been pregnant before, not even a scare, so yeah, disappointing. So that night I drank and I was right back in. Tonight, 6 hours from now, I will have completed 15 alcohol-free days in a row, the most since those 22 days that I prepared to be someone's mother. That was last March. 15 days doesn't sound like much to anyone who isn't subscribed to this subreddit. But it's everything to me and the challenge is going to teach me a lot about myself. I am excited to pass 22 days.

I have always had the mind set that weed is perfectly fine in moderation. I am definitely not using in moderation and realize i should quit. I love this place and find you guys really helpful. I'm just one person in one town in one country out of the billions and billions of other people that are in the world, the chances are little better than impossible. But even so, <e1>its just always in the back of my mind and regularly stops me posting here and asking you guys for help</e1>, because <e2>I'm worried that someone who knows me will somehow stumble across it</e2>, add 2+2 together and somehow get 76.Anyone else get that?

<e1>My parents have gone to Europe on vacation</e1> and <e2>I've been having bad bouts of anxiety since they left</e2>. I am in college so I do not live with them currently, but I don't worry about them when I know they're safe at home. Since they've left I wake up every morning with my heart pounding feeling nauseated. Yesterday I threw up a few times in the morning before finally giving up and taking one of my emergency Ativan. They're coming back next Saturday so in theory I could just ride it out, knowing I'll be alright once they come back. However, I have midterms this week and I really would love to not be vomiting and be able to keep down food.Any advice? I'm just frustrated with myself...EDIT: <e3>I also ideally would not like to have to take an Ativan every day for the next week</e3> because <e4>they're really only supposed to be for emergencies</e4>. However, I'm worried I won't be able to eat much without taking them.

I tried and tried. I just couldn't do it. I opened up steam and started to browse. I went to the old games I used to play and searched for new games too. In the end, I just couldn't bring myself to download anything or open up what was already installed.I failed to find a game that was intriguing enough to relieve me of my temporary boredom. I needed to look. It was always in the back of my mind. Now I know there is nothing left for me in the virtual world. There is too much to do around me. Even in my down time there is so much I can do that video games used to take from meIf you are done with your 90 days and games are nagging in the back of your head, take a look at them. You will realize you aren't missing anything and go back to really living.

For years I thought I was ADHD, personality disorders, or anything else. But after taking Paxil 30 mg every day, and 2mg Klonopin at night, I wake up happy, I talk to people, I am thoroughly happy and have no setbacks. It has taken me 10 plus years to finally figure this out. I wanted to control my anxiety without meds, but I realized that isn't possible. I will forever be on meds but if that means my life is happy and I have no limit on what I can do mentally and emotionally, consider me happy to be medicated. Just wanted to share my story.

Hey guys! I had an appointment with my psychiatrist on Tuesday where I discussed with her my increasing unhappiness with my job (I've only had customer service jobs since college).I told her half-jokingly, half-seriously that I was toying with the idea of going to medical school and becoming a doctor. For one, I know I'd be good at it. Two, there is such a scarcity of good psychiatrists and I want to fill the gap and be a great resource to those who need the help just as I needed it.My doctor didn't seem to think this was me being manic, but a career change (going from economics and political science, to working customer service jobs, to going to med school) seems like a big undertaking and I'm wondering if maybe it is a little bit manic of me to want to change my life.OR is it just me finally finding the motivation to do something different with my life? How can you tell?

Does anyone else out there have almost all of their anxiety primarily stem around work? Even when I'm not there, I am almost constantly thinking about it. Been this way for over 2 years now, despite not having any major problems or write ups with supervisors. Tonight I wrote my cycle down just to physically see it:Monday-Friday = Anxiety around 10pm until falling asleep. Anxiety and dread upon waking up, anywhere from 6-8am. Friday-Saturday night = extreme relief, feeling of happiness and freedom. Sunday afternoon = slow creep of existential dread. Feeling slight pit in bottom of stomach. Sunday night = worst of all. Total dread and anxiety take over of mind. Contemplate quitting job. Contemplate embarrassment shame over quitting said job. Proceed to weigh pros of quitting vs. cons of quitting. -Repeat on a weekly basis and wash down with some vodka sodas every weekend night. Am I the only one with obsessiveness like this? I have had 2 career type jobs, decently paid with no write ups or concerns, yet this always happens...sigh.

Hi guys,So, I've been prescribed 50mg vyvanse (extended release) for about two years now (I'm currently 21). While it has helped me tremendously get through my busy and hectic day, I find that it is not working as well as it used to. I take my vyvanse M-F, and sometimes every day of the week if I am working weekends (which lately has been more often than not). Every day I take it at 7AM. Before the past 5 months, I could take my vyvanse in the morning with breakfast and have it hard-working throughout the day until around 330PM. But now, I take my vyvanse at 7AM and by noon I can feel myself becoming inattentive, unfocused, scatter-brained, etc. I have tried different things to see if it would affect the duration of my dosage such as changing my eating schedule, changing the time I take it, drinking coffee halfway through, etc. Nothing has worked, and everyday I am getting more and more frustrated with myself.Do I need a higher mg? I've been taking antidepressants the past few weeks and making an effort not to be miserable. And after a series of marginal improvements, I managed to make it through a long Monday (pretty much going non-stop from 10AM-10PM) without any feelings of self-loathing, suicidal thoughts, hating my life, outbursts of rage, or episodes of intense stress or anxiety. I actually made it through the whole day without letting my mood plunge to its very depths. There were a few times when I started to feel stress or anxiety creep up on me today, but I was able to take a deep breath and let the things that I could do nothing about go. This was just another day in my life and yet I feel so accomplished! I have four more days to go, but this one was the longest (the others are still fairly long though). I wonder if I can keep this up and if it will get easier with time. I still anticipate bad days and backsliding, but hopefully they grow ever fewer and further between.

TL;DR: What positive things attributes/experiences do you think having ADHD has added to your experience as a person on this planet?I know this comes up sometimes, but I feel like a lot of people are struggling right now. Between those of us in school (Midterms time), those of us at work (Oh god when did summer end?!?), and everything else life can throw at us-- What do you like about having ADHD? <e1>I personally like that I have a lot of experience and knowledge about all kinds of things</e1> because <e2>I have found so many things to be interesting at one point or another</e2>. I find that I am generally more willing to try new things than my friends.  I love that through all my struggles, I want to get better, I want to improve, and sometimes I succeed at that- others I don't.  I think it has helped me be more self compassionate. I also feel like I have a better outlook on those living with mental illness, and I am glad I have compassion for those people instead of viewing them as broken" or "defective" like some people do.  "

I just feel like I've burned so many bridges, ruined so many opportunities, there's no out but dying. <e1>I had fooled myself into thinking I could face the world because I had people who cared by my side</e1>, so <e2>of course I had to ruin that by acting crazy splitting on one of them</e2>. The other one keeps trying to hold on to me, and I just feel like I'm dragging her down. They deserve better than me, and I'll never be up to par. I just wish I could shut this all off, maybe then what was left would be good, but I can't. So I guess my life is just prepping and counting down until my planned date. Sorry for the rant, I needed to let it out.

I'm thinking about taking a walk up to AA this afternoon, just to sit and observe and see if it's for me. Today...I won't drink

Hi all, First off, I absolutely love this subreddit. <e1>I was diagnosed with ADHD in grade five</e1>, so <e2>finding a huge group of people in all walks of life who have this is incredible</e2>, so thank you. I take Concerta, and I have since my first diagnosis. <e3>I didn't take Adderal or Ritalin</e3> due to <e4>an extremely addictive personality</e4>, and <e5>my family was worried about substance abuse becoming a future issue</e5>. So, I'm still with Concerta. Now, I love the effects and how well it makes me focus, but I find that it really hinders my diet, to the point that I gag whenever I try to eat on bad days, and recently that's been really taking a toll on my body, causing migraines and nausea. You'd think or hope that after a decade or so of medication, I'd know how to combat this, but I really don't. If anyone has the same issue, how do you combat it?

Hi all, I searched a lot but didn't come up with much about this besides a handful of posts, and none were very similar.I'm a recently diagnosed (but long time sufferer) of adult ADHD-PI. Was originally prescribed generic Concerta 36mg extended release. No noticeably positive effects, but the side effects start a few hours in and last the entire rest of the day: Jitteriness, strong anxiety, scatterbrain, feeling on edge all day, and finally depression. (Also dry mouth, lack of appetite, etc)I tried Focalin and Adderall IR up to 30mg, but only got the same exact results. I'm normally a very positive person and don't have any anxiety at all. Does anyone else have experience with this? <e1>My doctor is recommending Strattera</e1> so <e2>I guess I'll give that a try</e2>, but I'm very curious as to how common this is.

<e1>My doctor is on the fence about whether I have ADHD or not</e1>. <e2>I exhibit classic symptoms e.g. Procrastination, un organization, the cycle obsessing on a certain thing then shifting to something else quickly and then obsessing about it until I find a new thing, inability to focus when reading textbooks( I can focus when reading for pleasure), having to memorize everything because no amount of rereading will make it stick, etc.)</e2> however, he is on the fence because <e3>I was able to get acceptable grades (Bs and Cs) in high school</e3>. As I mentioned, the only way I got those grades is by memorizing. If i were to be tested on something that I understood when it was taught but have not memorized yet, I would fail. This even applied to technical subjects like science. Another reason why he is on the fence is because I have anxiety and OCD and he thinks they might be the reason why I am exhibiting those symptoms.  Does anybody have similar experiences? If he ends up prescribing me Ritalin or Concerta, will it have an effect on me if I don't have ADHD?

What can I do to decrease the restlessness? I don't want to stop, I enjoy running and I know it's good for me, but not being able to sit still sucks. I've been thinking of asking my doctor to increase my dosage (40mg Strattera daily) but I don't know. Me and my husband want to start trying for a baby next year which means I'll have to go off medication completely, and I don't think I want to come down from a higher dose, just going off this dose when my blood pressure spiked was terrible. Help?

Hello friends!This thread is the latest installment of the general catch-all discussion thread here at r MaladaptiveDreaming aimed at discussing anything and everything related to Maladaptive Dreaming. If you have any idle questions, have a great story to get off your chest, or simply want to shoot the breeze, then this thread is the place for you! There are also weekly prompts for anyone feeling shy about starting a conversation out of the blue. This weeks question is from u DimmerSwitchDisco What puts the "mal" in maladaptive for you? The time and brain resources? Does it make you feel bad about yourself? Or maybe you love the DD and it's just the pacing you can't stand? Etc.

I have rOCD and lately I feel like I've just been stuck in a self-fulfilling rut. I'm constantly worried that I'm pushing the people I care about away by carrying through with my checks and compulsions, and in doing so I am actually pushing them away, which makes the intrusive thoughts come on even stronger.I just got in touch with a friend I haven't seen or spoken to in almost 10 years and it's been so nice catching up with him. I'm terrified of losing him again, which in a way has actually really helped. If I can distract myself enough from my thoughts by digging into a hands on activity, I can almost reason with my thoughts and talk myself down.My thoughts have still by no means come close to stopping, and I still have my bad days, but they've been in the minority the past couple of weeks.I just wanted to share a small victory with a group that understands.

Hello guys, first of all I'm not addicted to any drug. Screw them, they are taking my precious time.So I'm doing something that makes me happy after work. I play games and code websites. Anybody else ever try this method?Apparently my [History of Rock and Jazz] notes cause dizziness and headaches in certain people, but somehow they make perfect sense to me.

I live in Durham region, I believe I have ADHD and my GP requires an assessment, which is done by private psychologists here. They charge around $300 for initial talk then $200-$250 hourly for assessment (6-10 hours: 1500 - 2800, plus 13% sales tax: 1700-3200). Minimum wage here is about $11.50.I'm curious about whether you need to be physically present for the assessment of ADHD, and if not, if there are any licensed, reputable psychiatrists or psychologists working overseas who do this assessment via the internet (skype, etc.).I'm also curious about how to encourage my GP to accept their credentials and diagnosis. Hello reddit,I'd just like to share with you a tool that has helped me develop new healthy habits, and fight procrastination.I read in some book (forgot the name) about anEDIT : <e1>I found the book - It's Mini Habits by Stephen Guise</e1>. This is what <e2>started the habit for me</e2>. 1% rule.  This is a method used to create new habits, but it can be applied to almost any situation.It functions off the perception that accomplishing something so small can add up. Say you want to make writing a habit, but cant get around to it.So you write ONE word. There, you're done.It's silly isn't it? But strangely you've accomplished your goal, and here you are either laughing about how stupid what you're doing is or feeling hopeful for a breakthrough.Regardless, that is apparently how neural pathways work. You need to reinforce them. There is NO EASIER way to break down successes into miniscule chunks until they become large enough to have an impact on your life. Chances are if you're a hard working ADHD'er, you'll try to push more than 1% or one word.You'll write two. Then three. Then ten. Until you feel accomplished". Then before long

since im like 13 i have the feeling of being in the enemies land camp. imagine your country is at war and youve been dropped off by parachute in the enemies land and now you are afraid that someone else discovers that you are one of the enemies through the way you dress, bevahave, speak. you have to cover your fear. you avoid attention by any means. you have to fake a whole personality. you wish you were invisible and could finally relax and be yourself and dont have to pretend to be someone else. its exhausting and does never stop. you are trapped, because you cant even kill yourself because you dont want your freinds and family to live with that. you are locked in a moral torture prison. i think i have social phobia.

Or perhaps even Aspergers. I have no diagnosis but generally when playing music you communicate. You have to play in equal tempo, send signals with your body language to make sue everyone is doing their thing on cue including yourself and it just became one dose of sensory overload after the other. I genuinely love playing guitar and attempt to write music, but the social aspect killed it for me.Part of me wants to get back in the game, but I know the social aspect is gonna topple me all over again. For the record, I've played in concerts both as a backing member and as a rhythm guitarist in a smaller band, even taken solos where the focus was on me. I fear practicing the music with close communication in my band more than playing in front of a crowd. I get butterflies in my stomach and visible shake during concerts but it's more adrenaline and normal stage fright than social anxiety. The thing that kills me is communicating with the band members regularly and it sucks but I'm too afraid to restart that hobby or potentially career choice.

I drove on the highway for the first time today. I kept creeping to the right shoulder but otherwise did fairly well. The thing is that even though my girlfriend told me I did well and that she was proud of me, I could only focus on what I did wrong.  I didn't wreck her car, we're both still alive, and overall I guess I did a few right things.I made the mistake of honesty. When she asked me how I thought it went, I told her I thought I was an utter failure. We talked back and forth about how I developed an all-or-nothing outlook on my own life, and at the end of it she said, I regret urging you to practice today."I've spent the last few hours feeling horrible and dreading seeing her again. I guess the moral here is to make sure that your support system can handle the burden of your stress. The burden of you. "

Hey Reddit world!My dad is a champion and he is team captain for a charity walk this weekend. The walk is raising funds and awareness for an organization called NAMI.
